title: Scenario 1: The Bottleneck
scenario: A cross-functional project is due tomorrow. You have completed your portion perfectly, but a teammate is behind because they struggled with a technical hurdle. This teammate is your peer.

options.label: A
options.text: Send your completed work to the manager immediately to show you’ve met your deadline.

options.label: B
options.text: Offer to hop on a call with the teammate to share your process and help them troubleshoot.

options.label: C
options.text: Wait for the teammate to ask for help; you don’t want to overstep or make them feel incompetent.

options.label: D
options.text: Check your work one more time to ensure your "A+" is secured, then head home.

title: Scenario 2: The Knowledge Discovery
scenario: You’ve discovered a shortcut in the company software that saves you two hours of manual data entry every week.

options.label: A
options.text: Keep it to yourself so you can use that extra time for personal projects and stand out.

options.label: B
options.text: Mention it to your manager during your next 1-on-1 to show your individual innovation.

options.label: C
options.text: Document the process and share it with the team so everyone can save time.

options.label: D
options.text: Use the shortcut but only share it if you see someone else specifically struggling.

title: Scenario 3: The Unearned Praise
scenario: During a meeting, your manager praises you for a brilliant idea that was actually sparked by a casual comment a teammate made during lunch.

options.label: A
options.text: Accept the praise; it was your execution that made the idea work anyway.

options.label: B
options.text: Thank the manager, then privately tell the teammate later that you appreciated their input.

options.label: C
options.text: Immediately speak up: "I can't take full credit; [Name] brought up the core concept."

options.label: D
options.text: Say "The team worked hard on this," without naming the specific person.

title: Scenario 4: The Ownership Dilemma
scenario: A client sends an urgent request that falls into a "gray area"—it’s not strictly your job, but the person who handles it is out sick. The client is getting frustrated.

options.label: A
options.text: Explain to the client that the responsible party is out and give them a return date.

options.label: B
options.text: Try to resolve the issue yourself to protect the team’s reputation and help the client.

options.label: C
options.text: Forward the email to your manager so they can decide who should handle it.

options.label: D
options.text: Ignore the email; responding might set a precedent that you are now responsible for this.

title: Scenario 5: The Team Mistake
scenario: Your team missed a deadline. Your manager asks the group what went wrong. You know it was because a teammate forgot an approval, but you also could have checked in on them.

options.label: A
options.text: Stay silent and let the teammate explain themselves; it’s their responsibility.

options.label: B
options.text: Say, "It was a breakdown in communication. I should have followed up to confirm."

options.label: C
options.text: Message the manager after the meeting to clarify exactly whose fault it was.

options.label: D
options.text: Make up a technical excuse (like a server error) to keep everyone out of trouble.

title: Scenario 6: The Documentation Request
scenario: You lead a complex process only you know. Your manager asks for a "How-To" manual so others can step in if you are ever unavailable.

options.label: A
options.text: Create a brief outline but leave out the nuances; some things are better learned by doing.

options.label: B
options.text: Create a comprehensive guide so simple that a junior member could handle it.

options.label: C
options.text: Suggest it’s more efficient for you to just do it, as teaching others takes too long.

options.label: D
options.text: Use the request as leverage to ask for a promotion or raise before sharing the info.

title: Scenario 7: The Weekend Emergency
scenario: It is Saturday. An urgent issue arises that requires info only you have. Your manager asks for 10 minutes of your time.

options.label: A
options.text: Ignore the message until Monday; weekends are a strictly "no-work" zone.

options.label: B
options.text: Provide the info quickly, then suggest a meeting Monday to ensure others have this info.

options.label: C
options.text: Handle the issue, but remind the manager Monday how "lost" the team would be without you.

options.label: D
options.text: Block work contacts during off-hours to ensure your time is never interrupted.
